utterances: It's hard to ignore Britney Spears.

Our estimate, which we call a back-of-the-napkin calculation because it's so rooted in science, was 110 to 120 million a year.
The Britney economy is - it'll be equivalent of, you know, 50- to 75,000-people strong company.
She is a gold mine for paparazzi.
One of the agencies in Los Angeles estimated to - she alone accounts for 30 percent of their revenues.
Kevin Federline, Britney Spear's ex-husband - now, do you count him as part of the Britney industrial complex, or is he subsidiary because (unintelligible)?
He isn't one of the three main spokes of the Britney industrial complex, which are the packagers, the paparazzi and the media.
We thought of him more of in the sycophant portion of the industrial complex.
He is pouring in about a million a year as a result of a bit sort of coming into the Britney orbit.
The media, we put at 75 million a year.
There must be concern about a Britney recession.
The Britneyconomy is big enough to tolerate changes in its complexion.

We talked to the people at Yahoo Search, and they said that for six of the past seven years, she has been the number one searched term on Yahoo, falling into second place, only once in 2004 when Paris Hilton briefly took the crown.
But if you look at that, that's seven years.
That's an economic cycle.
So Britney - the Britney economy may be impervious to the overall economy.
Duff McDonald at Portfolio magazine.

We represent well over a trillion dollars in investment assets.
So we aren't just a small group of fringe investors asking the SEC to take this action.
One of the nation's biggest power providers, American Electric Power, already mentions climate change in its financial reports.
Tom Berkemeyer is a lawyer for the company.

We basically describe that if greenhouse gas emission rules or legislation does come into being sometime in the future, it's likely to have a material affect on the financial condition of the company.
But AEP doesn't say much more than that.
Berkemeyer says that's because the Congress hasn't decided how to regulate greenhouse gas emissions.
Analyst Pete Wallison says the SEC is sure to turn down the petitioners' request.
Because the rules already require companies to do exactly what they're asking if it represents any kind of real threat or additional cost that they will have to bear in the future.
Wallison works for the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington think tank that favors limited government.
He says the reason companies don't say more about climate change is that the risks pale in comparison to others.
This one would fall way, way down the list of potential costs to companies.
For example, there's a lot of political risk right now about health insurance costs.
There's political risk about tax changes, interest rate changes.
But Georgetown University law professor Donald Langevoort says it's time for the SEC to require companies to focus more on global warming.
And the assumption that climate change really is going to change the cost of doing business.
It's important that companies focus their attention on this, and disclosure can be healthy in that regard.
The state treasurers hope that if the SEC requires more disclosure, that will prod companies to do more to cut back their greenhouse gas emissions.
Elizabeth Shogren, NPR News, Washington.
Welcome back to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.

And he really praised Ghana in particular.
